zone.line: I do not say that if his own desires
had been put in competition with those
of others that he would have displayed
undue selfishness, but this trial was
never made. He was nurtured in prospe
rity and attended by all its advantages;
everyone loved him and wished to gra-
tify him. He was ever employed in
promoting the h pleasures of his compa-
nions â€“ th but their pleasures were his;
and if he bestowed more attention upon
the feelings of others than is usual with
schoolboys it was because his social
temper could never enjoy itself if every
brow was not as free from care as his
own. While at
While at school, emulation and
his own natural abilities made him
hold a conspicuous rank in the forms
among his equals; At colled college
he discarded books; he believed that he
had other lessons to learn than those
